For the preceding conference see Zbl 1230.52004.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35Q35 35A01 76S05 Brinkman flow equation; well-posedness serial article Urrea, José Jiménez Number: 6109995 The Cauchy problem associated to the regularized Brinkman flow equation in math1 . 2013 Summary: The existence of solutions to the regularized Brinkman flow equation with initial data in math2 is shown. This result improves the previous results.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 60-01 60J60 60J65 book Gillespie, Daniel Thomas; Seitaridou, Effrosyni Number: 6110084 Simple Brownian diffusion. An introduction to the standard theoretical models. 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher’s description: Brownian diffusion is the motion of one or more solute molecules in a sea of very many, much smaller solvent molecules. Its importance today owes mainly to cellular chemistry, since Brownian diffusion is one of the ways in which key reactant molecules move about inside a living cell. This book focuses on the four simplest models of Brownian diffusion: the classical Fickian model, the Einstein model, the discrete-stochastic (cell-jumping) model, and the Langevin model. The authors carefully develop the theories underlying these models, assess their relative advantages, and clarify their conditions of applicability. Special attention is given to the stochastic simulation of diffusion, and to showing how simulation can complement theory and experiment. Two self-contained tutorial chapters, one on the mathematics of random variables and the other on the mathematics of continuous Markov processes (stochastic differential equations), make the book accessible to researchers from a broad spectrum of technical backgrounds.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35J60 35B35 stability; sharpness results serial article Navarro, Miguel Angel; Villegas, Salvador Number: 6109992 The sharpness of some results on stable solutions of math1 in math2 . 2013 Summary: In this note we give a complete answer to a question raised by L. Dupaigne and A. Farina [Nonlinear Anal., Theory Methods Appl. 70, No. 8, A, 2882–2888 (2009; Zbl 1167.35364)] related to the existence of nonconstant stable solutions of the equation math3 in math4 , where math5 and math6 is a very general non-negative, non-decreasing and convex nonlinearity.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 65K10 93C10 93C15 93B30 iterative identification; Hammerstein models; maximum likelihood; Newton iteration; nonlinear optimization; parameter estimation; algorithm; Hammerstein nonlinear controlled autoregressive autoregressive moving average systems; numerical examples serial article Li, Junhong Number: 6107002 Parameter estimation for Hammerstein CARARMA systems based on the Newton iteration. 2013 Summary: The Newton iteration is basic for solving nonlinear optimization problems and studying parameter estimation algorithms. In this letter, a maximum likelihood estimation algorithm is developed for estimating the parameters of Hammerstein nonlinear controlled autoregressive autoregressive moving average (CARARMA) systems by using the Newton iteration. A simulation example is provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C69 05C76 global offensive alliances; domination; Cartesian product graphs serial article Yero, Ismael G.; Rodríguez-Velázquez, Juan A. Number: 1254.05143 Computing global offensive alliances in Cartesian product graphs. 2013 Summary: A global offensive alliance in a graph math1 is a set math2 of vertices with the property that every vertex not belonging to math3 has at least one more neighbor in S than it has outside of S. The global offensive alliance number of math4 , math5 , is the minimum cardinality of a global offensive alliance in math6 . A set math7 of vertices of a graph math8 is a dominating set for math9 if every vertex not belonging to math10 has at least one neighbor in math11 . The domination number of math12 , math13 , is the minimum cardinality of a dominating set of math14 . In this work we obtain closed formulas for the global offensive alliance number of several families of Cartesian product graphs, we also prove that math15 for any graphs math16 and math17 and we show that if math18 has an efficient dominating set, then math19 . Moreover, we present a Vizing-like conjecture for the global offensive alliance number and we prove it for several families of graphs.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 60 renewal-reward process; Brownian motion; jump-diffusion process; passage time serial article Blanchet-Scalliet, Christophette; Dorobantu, Diana; Rullière, Didier Number: 6107005 The density of a passage time for a renewal-reward process perturbed by a diffusion. 2013 Summary: Recently, Coutin and Dorobantu (2011) [1] show the existence of the density for the first passage time math1 of a level x by X, where X is a Lévy process with a compound Poisson process and a Gaussian component. In this note, we generalize their result and we consider X a mixed process, the sum of a Brownian motion and a renewal-reward process. Our result (the density of math2 ) may be computed in classical settings (for a Lévy process) and also in a non-Markovian context with possible positive and negative jumps. Compared to Coutin and Dorobantu (2011) [1], we also derive some relations allowing us to build the conditional density when we observe the paths of X only at jump times. The main advantage of a density formula is that we may obtain the passage time probability with fewer simulations than for an empirical cumulative distribution function of the passage time. Numerical applications illustrate the interest of this result.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 34-02 34Dxx 37C75 book Martynyuk, Anatoly; Chernetskaya, Larisa; Martynyuk, Vladislav Number: 6110079 Weakly connected nonlinear systems. Boundedness and stability of motion. 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher’s description: Weakly Connected Nonlinear Systems: Boundedness and Stability of Motion provides a systematic study on the boundedness and stability of weakly connected nonlinear systems, covering theory and applications previously unavailable in book form. It contains many essential results needed for carrying out research on nonlinear systems of weakly connected equations. After supplying the necessary mathematical foundation, the book illustrates recent approaches to studying the boundedness of motion of weakly connected nonlinear systems. The authors consider conditions for asymptotic and uniform stability using the auxiliary vector Lyapunov functions and explore the polystability of the motion of a nonlinear system with a small parameter. Using the generalization of the direct Lyapunov method with the asymptotic method of nonlinear mechanics, they then study the stability of solutions for nonlinear systems with small perturbing forces. They also present fundamental results on the boundedness and stability of systems in Banach spaces with weakly connected subsystems through the generalization of the direct Lyapunov method, using both vector and matrix-valued auxiliary functions. Designed for researchers and graduate students working on systems with a small parameter, this book will help readers get up to date on the knowledge required to start research in this area.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 62-01 62P30 book Montgomery, Douglas C. Number: 6108240 Statistical quality control. A modern introduction. 7th ed., International Student Version. 2013 Publisher’s description: The Seventh Edition of Statistical Quality Control provides a comprehensive treatment of the major aspects of using statistical methodology for quality control and improvement. Both traditional and modern methods are presented, including state-of-the-art techniques for statistical process monitoring and control and statistically designed experiments for process characterization, optimization, and process robustness studies. The seventh edition continues to focus on DMAIC (define, measure, analyze, improve, and control–the problem-solving strategy of six sigma) including a chapter on the implementation process. Additionally, the text includes new examples, exercises, problems, and techniques. Statistical Quality Control is best suited for upper-division students in engineering, statistics, business and management science or students in graduate courses.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 65M32 35G50 65R30 optimal design; inverse problems; optimal selection of observables; sampling points; parameter estimation; complex nonlinear partial differential systems; iterative algorithm serial article Banks, H.T.; Rehm, K.L. Number: 6106987 Experimental design for distributed parameter vector systems. 2013 Summary: We formulate an optimal design problem for the selection of best states to observe and optimal sampling times and locations for parameter estimation or inverse problems involving complex nonlinear partial differential systems. An iterative algorithm for implementation of the resulting methodology is proposed.
